title: 113_s2709
content: The Export-Import Bank Reauthorization Act of 2014 extends the authority of the Export-Import Bank Act of 1945 until 2019. It also includes provisions on information technology systems and the establishment of a Sub-Saharan Africa advisory committee. SEC. 3. Information technology systems are updated to include years 2015-2019. SEC. 4. The Sub-Saharan Africa advisory committee is now effective until 2019. SEC. 5. Limitations on loans, guarantees, and insurance. Section 6(a)(2) of the Export-Import Bank Act of 1945 is amended to adjust funding amounts for fiscal years 2012, 2013, and 2014. The funding amount for fiscal year 2015 and beyond is set at $145,000,000,000, with a potential increase to $150,000,000,000 for fiscal year 2016. The funding amount for fiscal year 2016 could potentially increase to $150,000,000,000 if certain conditions are met as per the Export-Import Bank Reauthorization Act. The funding amount for fiscal year 2017 is $155,000,000,000, and for fiscal year 2018 and beyond, it is $160,000,000,000, subject to specific conditions outlined in the Export-Import Bank Reauthorization Act. The funding amount for fiscal year 2017 is $155,000,000,000, and for fiscal year 2018 and beyond, it is $160,000,000,000, subject to conditions specified in the Export-Import Bank Reauthorization Act, including interest rate calculations. SEC. 6 amends Public Law 103-428 by changing the year from 2014 to 2019. SEC. 7 requires a business plan for exposure limit. The Export-Import Bank of the United States must submit a report to Congress and the Comptroller General within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. The report should include a business plan with estimates of exposure limits, growth projections, and details on industry sectors and types of financial products for fiscal years 2015 through 2019. An analysis of the potential risks to the Export-Import Bank due to estimated exposure limits, including changes in exposure composition by industry sector, product, and key market. Additionally, an assessment of the Bank's ability to meet mandates for small businesses, sub-Saharan Africa, and carbon policy under the proposed exposure limit, as well as an evaluation of the Bank's resources for processing, approving, and monitoring effectively. The Bank will process, approve, and monitor authorizations under the proposed exposure limit. The Comptroller General will review the report and business plan, submitting a report to Congress with recommendations within 180 days. Government Accountability Office will conduct a study on medium-term financing programs. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the medium-term financing programs of the Export-Import Bank to identify risks to taxpayers, program soundness, and compliance with policies. The study will also assess steps taken by the Bank to address identified practices. Past findings by the Inspector General will be considered, and a report is due within one year of the enactment of the Act. The Comptroller General will submit a report to the Senate and House committees on the results of a study on the Export-Import Bank's medium-term financing programs, including recommendations for further action.
